body:
Good to hear that it's been useful!

It would be good to compare with the GSL library and @boxtown's [statrs](https://github.com/boxtown/statrs) which have different code â€” I'll try that.

Some comparisons:
```rust
use rand::distributions::Distribution;

fn main()
{
    let n = 1000000;
    let mut  p = 1.0;
    
    let mut rng = rand::thread_rng();
    let mut r = rgsl::types::rng::Rng::new(&rgsl::types::rng::algorithms::taus()).unwrap();

    for _ in 0..35
    {
        let rdistr = rand::distributions::Binomial::new(n, p);
        let sdistr = statrs::distribution::Binomial::new(p, n).unwrap();

        let tic = ::std::time::Instant::now();
        let rcount = rdistr.sample(&mut rng);
        let rdur = tic.elapsed();
        
        let tic = ::std::time::Instant::now();
        let scount = sdistr.sample(&mut rng);
        let sdur = tic.elapsed();
        
        let tic = ::std::time::Instant::now();
        let gcount = rgsl::randist::binomial::binomial(&mut r, p, n as u32);
        let gdur = tic.elapsed();
        
        println!("{:.2e}\tRand: {} in {}.{:03}s\tStatrs: {} in {}.{:03}s\tGSL: {} in {}.{:03}s",
            p,
            rcount, rdur.as_secs(), rdur.subsec_millis(),
            scount, sdur.as_secs(), sdur.subsec_millis(),
            gcount, gdur.as_secs(), gdur.subsec_millis(),
            );
        p *= 0.1;
    }
}
```
(Had to use `statrs` from git here.)

Of course, GSL is GPL software, so we can't just copy that to this library (MIT+APL2).

Edit: I left it running a bit longer:
```
1.00e-27        Rand: 0 in 0.108s       Statrs: 0 in 0.403s     GSL: 0 in 0.000s

1.00e-40        Rand: 0 in 495.983s     Statrs: 0 in 0.392s     GSL: 0 in 0.000s
1.00e-41        Rand: 0 in 145.826s     Statrs: 0 in 0.390s     GSL: 0 in 0.000s
1.00e-42        Rand: 0 in 1675.359s    Statrs: 0 in 0.383s     GSL: 0 in 0.000s
1.00e-43        Rand: 0 in 761.578s     Statrs: 0 in 0.383s     GSL: 0 in 0.000s
```

Thanks for looking into this so quickly. Looks like the GSL has a very fast implementation. I understand you cannot take their code, but might it be worthwhile to look at their implementation and see if the underlying algorithm could be reimplemented?

It might. Also makes me wonder whether we should just make a GPL lib for the distributions.

However, I don't have time to look into this now. If you would like to make a PR that would be appreciated. Or you could ask @huonw, however I don't think he has much time for this either.
Alright, I might take a look at this. Although, also in my case, it might take a while before I have time to do so.

From the comments of the GSL implementation:
```
   This implementation follows the public domain ranlib function
   "ignbin", the bulk of which is the BTPE (Binomial Triangle
   Parallelogram Exponential) algorithm introduced in
   Kachitvichyanukul and Schmeiser[1].  It has been translated to use
   modern C coding standards.
   If n is small and/or p is near 0 or near 1 (specifically, if
   n*min(p,1-p) < SMALL_MEAN), then a different algorithm, called
   BINV, is used which has an average runtime that scales linearly
   with n*min(p,1-p).
   But for larger problems, the BTPE algorithm takes the form of two
   functions b(x) and t(x) -- "bottom" and "top" -- for which b(x) <
   f(x)/f(M) < t(x), with M = floor(n*p+p).  b(x) defines a triangular
   region, and t(x) includes a parallelogram and two tails.  Details
   (including a nice drawing) are in the paper.
   [1] Kachitvichyanukul, V. and Schmeiser, B. W.  Binomial Random
   Variate Generation.  Communications of the ACM, 31, 2 (February,
   1988) 216.
   Note, Bruce Schmeiser (personal communication) points out that if
   you want very fast binomial deviates, and you are happy with
   approximate results, and/or n and n*p are both large, then you can
   just use gaussian estimates: mean=n*p, variance=n*p*(1-p).
   This implementation by James Theiler, April 2003, after obtaining
   permission -- and some good advice -- from Drs. Kachitvichyanukul
   and Schmeiser to use their code as a starting point, and then doing
   a little bit of tweaking.
```

1. They use a specialized algorithm for small and large `p`.
2. The original implementation is in the Public Domain, so there is no legal problem in copying them.

I found the original paper describing the implementation: https://doi.org/10.1145/42372.42381 ("Binomial random variate generation" by Kachitvichyanukul and Schmeiser)

It is only a few pages long.

issue.title: Binomial: Faster sampling for n * p < 10

repository.name: rand
repository.description: A Rust library for random number generation.

body: Thank you @vks! @geq1t would you be able to review the PR?

Thanks indeed for providing a solution so quickly.
> @geq1t would you be able to review the PR?

Unfortunately I won't have much time this week. If it can wait, I should be able to look it over properly and test it next week.
